section.title: Group
section.p: A group represents a set of one or more subscribers (as devices) or one or more groups and is uniquely identified by a name. That is, a group can have subscriptions associated to it (similar to a device), and have a list of devices who have membership to that group. It is possible for groups to have a hierarchy associated to them; for example, a group containing groups which contain devices.
A group contains the information about its child groups and devices. This helps to traverse top to bottom in hierarchy.

The general purpose of a group is to share a common set of resources or a service. Members of a group have access to the group’s associated services. To control that access, capabilities and attributes must be provided to define the control of accessing the shared resource.

The general purpose of nested groups is to provide a functionality of inheritance. Members of a group not only access services associated to the group, but also the services of group’s lineage (parent group, grandparent group, and so on).

section.title: Group associations and hierarchy
section.p: Groups can contain (membership) a large number of devices or other groups in a hierarchy to provide for more efficient provisioning when assigning services and when quota redistribution is necessary within a group. A device can belong to more than one group. The same is true for groups as they can be members of more than one higher-level group. Groups can be used for family plans, multi-device plans (including M2M), or prepaid and online postpaid plans.
